Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I glanced at the clock, knowing my shift was almost over. My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie: “Rough day, can’t wait to see you.” I pictured their tired face, the way they’d want to talk, maybe just sit together in silence. I wanted to be there, to listen, to offer comfort. But right in front of me, my new client frowned at her reflection, lips pressed tight. “It’s a bit warmer than I expected,” she said, voice trembling with disappointment. My heart sank. I needed to fix this, to reassure her, to make sure she left happy—my reputation depended on it. But Jamie’s words echoed in my mind, tugging at me. I felt split in two, torn between the urge to rush home and the duty to stay, to make things right for my client. My hands shook as I reached for the colour chart, my mind racing with what I owed to both of them, and the fear of letting either one down.
